it's not.....or is it? hehe. best tag line for these series. Looking deeper into film, yeah, that's what I wish people should understand, know, and value... films aren't just good clear stories, special effects, CGIs, famous actors, and happy endings......it's a mirror of of some sort of our life on a 2D screen, and as we all know life, pretty sure we knew a little I guess, it's not that always a good and clear story, no special effects and magical scenes all the time, no CGIs but only weird imaginations and hallucinations, we are the main actor, and it's not always a happy ending for all.....
*actors = pertaining to general performers who does acting, both men and women who acts a character; in the context of film.

I wish you could talk about Citizen Kane without sounding like a snob. It's really, really good, and feels very modern. The way it's shot, the way people talk, the themes, all feel much more akin to what we see today, and not old-timey like Casablanca (which came out after Citizen Kane) or something. Which is probably fitting, since I'm sure it influenced all those "modern" movies that it feels at home alongside.

I love this subject, but am afraid that this course will focus only or ar least the majority of it's episodes on mainstream American cinema and frankly there is just too much content about that in youtube and not enough about other countries cinema. I also get the impression that that the course will be too superficial or at least too entry level, the questions he poses in this introduction about Citizen Kane and 2001 are not that difficult or interessting. 2001 is a movie that was so analyzed since it's release that probably nothing original would be said in a 15-30 minute crash course video. Besides saying that people consider 2001 to be almost incomprehensible is just not true. No one says that, at least no one intelectualy worthwhile. 2001 has been understood quite well for a while. Anyway, I hope to be wrong and that this course turns out a great source for understanding film.

This is awezome! I do love making films, watching films, analysing an reviewing them, but the one thing with films that make me paticular exiting is how film relates to us as human beings, how it manipulates us and effects us.

To me, the most important and crucial lesson in film is what films says about us as human beings. How WE as humans present ourselves to ourselves and each other.

Storytelling IS how we see the world and/or how we want the world to be seen, and Films in the global market is the few international language we can communicate to each other through culture, time and history about who we are, who we want to be and who we wish we were.

I love Crash Course, but this potential series makes me nervous. I really hope this doesn't end up creating a bunch of nitpicky wannabe amateurs.

For the record, I am a movie critic for the Autism Channel who prides himself in being a more casual laid-back reviewer in the vein of Jeremy Jahns or Roger Ebert (he's the most laid-back of the professional film critics so I'm counting him) to defy the stereotype that all film critics have to be highbrow snobs.

Plus the complete lack of blockbusters on this list disturbs me.

Like yes please, except all the internets have been doing this for (now) decades. So 1) Death of the Author. Right? Right seriously, you know what I'm talking about. 2) Adapting a book or comic or franchise to the "Silver screen"... there's no one way to do it. Being "true to the original" has its place, but is always flawed, you get that, right? 3) There are many worldwide audiences both for you and the films you'll be talking about. Don't always look at things from the US:? Please? 4) And the following: different media = different requirements! Let's celebrate what films do best.

I know you hinted about all this with the "or is it?" wink/nod/etc., but the weight placed on various interpretational frameworks could seriously hamper (or other large, bothering metaphor) this series!
